Author: Vevaseti

Comment: There are riches in space, if you care about that. There is great and strange beauty in space, if you care about that. There is knowledge in space, if you care about that. There is research to be done with earthbound applications, which I admit is an ass-backwards way of getting it done but at least it's fuckin' getting done in the middle of Trump's rampage.  But those are all trifles. The real reason I'm for space exploration is that, despite its infuriating start-stop-start crawl, it's the way to buy humanity more time to see beauty and do all that saccharine live laugh love crap. If we don't make it to space now, I'm not sure future civilizations will have a shot after this one collapses. We've worked our way through accessible metals, fossil fuels, etcetera. Moreover, in an even longer and more idealistic scale, it's the way to spread life from the one place it grows. Beyond our garden whose time, despite all its beauty and despite the unimaginable time scale, is limited.

Author: xpertdeltalol

Comment: The dime is fine; it costs less to produce than it is worth.  Pennies and nickels are a problem though, because the cost to produce them is more than the coins are worth. The nickel is actually the most egregious here, with the US government losing 8.78 cents for every nickel produced. The penny also isn’t great, with the government losing 2.69 cents for every penny produced.  However, abolishing the nickel is problematic because it would make change very awkward given the popularity of quarters here. Essentially, we would need to overhaul US coins for this to work. Alternatively, and IMO this is the more likely eventual outcome, we could choose a cheaper blend of materials with which to produce nickels.  Pennies, however, could be abolished easily. Other countries have already done this without issue, and let’s face it, the only purpose pennies serve at all these days is making exact change. Rounding cash transactions to the nearest 5 cents makes them completely unnecessary.
